text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with cold Yuba noodle salad that's
right I really don't mind doing
vegetarian recipes or paleo recipes or
raw recipes are gluten-free recipes I
just don't like to do them on purpose so
while this amazingly delicious and easy
salad is all those things that's not the
reason we're making it we want to make
this for no other reason than its
delicious to eat
okay so let's get started and this
really will work with any kind of
dressing but let me show you the one I
use which was a peanut vinaigrette so
we're gonna start with a couple
tablespoons as smooth peanut butter to
which we'll add a little bit of honey
and by the way I can never remember does
the honey mean this is not vegan I can
never figure that one out do the vegans
not eat honey if now you know what
that's kind of insulting to the bees but
anyway a little bit of honey and we're
also going to add some nice freshly
grated ginger root along with a decent
amount of some kind of ground chili
sauce I'm using sambal
but anything similar will work we're
also going to need some vegetable oil
I'm just gonna use canola and then last
but not least we're gonna pour in some
rice vinegar but here's a great tip heat
it first alright I warm this up in the
microwave and what that does is you stir
this in that's going to help melt that
peanut butter so I just wore mine up in
the microwave for a few seconds poured
it in and it really does make mixing
this up way more manageable so we're
going to keep whisking that tilts
emulsified perfectly and then I'm going
to give mine a little taste by the way
if someone's watching use a spoon and I
decided to do a little final seasoning
of fine tuning with a little bit of soy
sauce and a few drops of toasted sesame
oil and I'm going to stir that in and as
far as I'm concerned that peanut
vinaigrettes done as far as texture goes
I think this is perfect okay we want
this just thick enough to coat those
noodles if you want a little thicker you
could add a little more peanut butter
and if you want a thinner you could add
a little more oil and vinegar or a
splash of water okay but that's up to
you you're the one messing with the
dressing so make it how you want and
then once that's done let's go ahead and
set that aside and get to the star of
the show Yuba also known as tofu skin
which I know sounds incredibly delicious
but anyway this is how mine comes this
is a 5 ounce package it comes in two
pieces like this and it's going to be
all folded up so the first thing we're
going to do is unfold this and the good
news here is this is probably the
hardest part pull this apart without
tearing it by the way if you tear it
don't worry still going to work and have
to tell you this has such an inch
feel to it it's kind of slippery and
kind of sticky at the same time and it
really does look incredibly skin like I
mean even if you're not into cooking but
do the occasional low-budget horror film
you're going to want to check this stuff
out but anyway what we're going to do is
unfold this till we get down to a single
layer and then we're just going to roll
it up and start cutting and I'm going to
cut this and have to make it easier to
work with and in fact let me unroll this
piece and roll it up a little tighter so
I can make the point the tighter and
neater you roll this up the better your
noodles are going to look and come on
admit it you want good looking noodles
so I'm gonna roll that up nice and tight
and simply cut inch wide pieces and when
those are all separated and unrolled
you're going to have what looks like
flat wide noodles except this is all
made from tofu believe it or not and of
course I'm going to give a ton more info
on the blog about the nutritional
aspects of this but it really is kind of
a miracle food and that we're eating
something that really does seem and feel
like pasta and yet it's absolutely grain
free and very low in the carbs and cows
so I know it seems too good to be true
but every once in a great while things
that seem too good to be true actually
are true and this is one of those things
and then once that steps been
accomplished let's go ahead and transfer
that into a bowl and add the rest of the
ingredients first of which would be some
fresh raw carrot and sure you could
grade it or use your fancy vegetable
slicer but all I did was take a potato
peeler and make some nice thin ribbons
which is going to kind of mirror the
shape of the noodle I'm also going to
put in a handful of finely sliced
cabbage some freshly torn cilantro
leaves and I know some you can eat that
but you can substitute with basil or
mint also delicious in this and I'm also
going to throw in a little bit of green
onion and that's pretty much it and what
I like to do before we add the dressing
is give this a little tossing first kind
of mix up those vegetables in and around
the noodles so we're going to give it a
little pre toss here and then what I
like to do is add the dressing in a
couple additions so I'm going to put a
couple littles in here I'm going to give
it a toss see how it looks it won't be
enough but I knew that but I do like to
give it this initial coating and then
I'm going to put a couple more ladles in
give that a final mixing and evaluate
and for me that was just the right
amount not too wet not too dry and don't
forget you can always add more you can't
take it out so don't be afraid to mix in
a little time until it's perfect and
then once that's all been dressed and
tossed together you're ready to serve
so I went ahead and clean the sides of
the bowls because I got to take some
pictures I sprinkle down a few more
green onions and then just for a little
visual interest a little bit of contrast
I sprinkled on some black sesame seeds
that helps your eyes realize how
beautiful those colors are and that cold
Yuba noodle salad is done
sure looks beautiful sure looks like a
noodle salad but does it taste and feel
like a noodle salad and the answer to
that is very much yes ironically the
texture of this stuff is kind of how
noodles are supposed to be for a cold
noodle salad but rarely are chewy but
not tough firm but still tender enough
to bite through easily just a very very
delicious and unique experience and you
know that walk of shame you do the one
you do it like 2:00 in the morning down
to the refrigerator and you find that
leftover Chinese takeout and eat those
cold noodles in the dark kitchen they're
so delicious but then you start feeling
shame and guilt because it's so
unhealthy for you here you're going to
get all that delicious taste and texture
with none of the self-loathing and while
it was great in a bowl using a fork for
whatever reason this really does taste
better if you eat it with chopsticks so
I served a little bit up on the only
Asian looking plate I have you may
remember that play from such videos as
every Asian recipe I've ever done but
anyway like I said for whatever reason
it really does taste better on
chopsticks and right here you're
probably thinking man you're pretty good
at those chef Jon well you know what I'm
cheating oh yeah chef Jon's using the
clip-on tie of eating utensils
I believe that's officially the most
embarrassing thing I've ever admitted to
in one of these videos but anyway while
the chopsticks were fake all the other
things I've said about this amazing cold
Yuma noodle salad are real so real so I
really do hope you give this a try head
